Award.AwardTitle: SPIRIT: Scholarship Program Initiative via Recruitment, Innovation, and Transformation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The United States faces a national need to increase substantially the number of American scientists and engineers. This project at Western Carolina State University addresses this need by providing academic and financial support to students pursuing engineering and engineering technology degrees at that institution. This initiative is called SPIRIT: Scholarship Program Initiative via Recruitment, Innovation, and Transformation. SPIRIT creates a focused approach to the recruitment, retention, education, and placement of engineering and technology students with academic talent and financial need. This program helps to develop domestic, workforce ready, engineers by providing scholarships that will assist qualified SPIRIT scholars to reduce their financial burden for obtaining an undergraduate education. The project promotes diversity in STEM fields, specifically for lower income students in STEM.

The project will utilize student-centered strategies to achieve goals for student retention and success in engineering and engineering technology majors. The educational program focuses on problem-based learning communities that nurture technical skills and professional skills. Students will be recruited into horizontally and vertically integrated cohorts that are developed into a Project Based Learning (PBL) community. The community will be characterized by extensive faculty mentoring, fundamental and applied research, hands-on design projects, and industry engagement. The horizontal integration method creates sub-cohorts with same-year students from different disciplines such as electrical engineering or mechanical engineering working in an environment that reflects how engineers work in the real world. The vertical integration method will enable sub-cohorts from different years to work together on different stages of projects in a PBL setting. The objectives of the SPIRIT program are to ensure an interdisciplinary environment that enhances technical competency through learning outcomes. These outcomes address improvements in critical skills such as intentional learning, problem solving, teamwork, project management, interpersonal communications, and leadership.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SPIRIT: Scholarship Program Initiative via Recruitment, Innovation, and Transformation (SPIRIT) project encompasses five major program scholarship activities that engaged low-income engineering and engineering technology students in weekly meetings focused on: building a learning/support community; mentorship; vertically-integrated project-based learning (PBL); undergraduate research (UgR); and academic/career readiness.

Program recruitment yielded a diverse pool of 27 scholarship participants (16% Female, 11% African American, 5% American Indian, and 6 % Asian) with a wide-range of backgrounds and experiences. Program participant and degree retention rates were held at 82%, 4-year graduation rates were 89% with the remaining participants graduating in 4.5 years, and final average cumulative GPAs were 3.72/4.00. SPIRIT program participants produced 45 undergraduate research artifacts that were subsequently presented at both national and regional conferences. Four program participants sought to further deepen their UgR experience and subsequently participated in NSF REU opportunities. Nineteen in-session vertically integrated PBL group activities were followed by 1 Junior-level and  year-long, Senior-level, industry-sponsored group design projects. Post-graduation, 9 of the program participants were enrolled in engineering graduate programs, 17 were gainfully employed in a STEM related field, and 1 graduate was seeking gainful employment. The SPIRIT program directors sought to widely disseminated the framework, methodologies, and impact of several major program themes and activities through ten peer-reviewed presentations and/or publications.

The SPIRIT program was comprised of a diverse group of under-represented students, many who were first-generation college students and unaware of the pressures, expectations, and level of professionalism required of them during their academic and career pathways. Program activities and collaborations between the institution’s Center for Career and Profession Development, Writing and Learning Commons, Math Tutoring Center, and Student Support Services assisted to facilitate growth in academic and career readiness as well as the professional skills of the participants. Efforts in these areas impacted the participants’ continued participation in STEM related education opportunities at the graduate level and towards global competitiveness through post-employment in the STEM fields. Further, as apparent student role-models in the engineering and engineering technology programs, frequent participation in these activities along with dissemination through informal communication channels may have served as a positive influence on non-program peers in their respective majors.

The performance-based scholarships and the major program activities offered by the SPIRIT program successfully impacted the environment which fostered the positive results experienced in both retention and placement rates of the participants. Ninety-three percent of the participants strongly agreed or agreed that the SPIRIT program was the most beneficial extracurricular activity that they had participated in during their academic career. The UgR and vertically-integrated PBL activities served to provide personalized attention where the participants experienced both strong peer-peer and director-participant mentorship; artifact quality and quantity in each of these areas far exceeded the directors’ expectations.

With this, the SPIRIT program’s triangulated mentorship model shows convincing promise for providing an effective support system (persistence) for low-income, first generation, underrepresented engineering and engineering technology students, especially those students who may have the necessary academic ability but lack adequate preparation and guidance to be successful in an engineering major. Further, the prescribed SPIRIT program activities incorporating vertically integrated Project-Based Learning (PBL) made a positive impact in the professional skills and work-readiness of the program’s participants. Consequently, the school’s curriculum committee fully integrated the SPIRIT program’s vertically integrated PBL model into all degree programs through common interdisciplinary PBL courses: freshmen engineering introductory courses make use of five short-duration open-ended design projects and peer-peer mentoring activities; freshman, sophomore, and junior PBL courses use vertically integrated PBL and peer-to-peer mentorship through common design projects/challenges that require students to work in groups across multiple sections of the courses; and senior capstone project presentations are attended by freshmen and sophomore PBL classes followed by group reflection and discussion. Additionally, the SPIRIT program’s UgR success has impacted programs institutionally, where several Honor’s College UgR courses were created to compliment an institutional-wide undergraduate summer research experience. Overall, this project has produced, and will continue to produce, lasting impact on the participants, school, and institution.
